citations.narrative:
During inspection it was noted that six chow dogs and three six-month old puppies did not have any form of identification.
All dogs, including puppies, must have distinctive identification so that animals can be identified in the case of an animal
disease outbreak, and to identify specific animals that may require routine or veterinary care. Class “A” breeders shall
identify all dogs under his control or on his premises, whether held, purchased, or otherwise acquired.
All dogs and puppies held at the facility must have a distinctive identification.
Correction Date: July 22nd, 2024

The play yard that is primarily used for young dogs and smaller dogs had a hole that was dug under the south west most
kennel.
The hole could lead to dogs becoming stuck in the hole or in the flooring of the kennel above which could lead to injury of
the dogs.
Housing facilities for dogs and cats must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be
kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals
from entering.
Correction date: July 19th, 2024

There was no written exercise plan available at the time of inspection.
Exercise for dogs is critical for healthy development and psychological well-being.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with
the opportunity for exercise. In addition, the plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must include
written standard procedures to be followed in providing the opportunity for exercise.
Correction Date: July 22nd, 2024

There were no records of the adult dogs in the kennel receiving parvovirus and distemper vaccines. The facility
representative reported that the vaccines are normally given when the dogs whelp but it has not been done for the last
few litters. The is no program for when the males in the kennel are to be vaccinated.
Failure to vaccinate dogs leaves them vulnerable illness, and disease that could lead to death.
Each breeder must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing,
and signed by the attending veterinarian. Breeders must keep and maintain the written program and make it available for
APHIS inspection. The written program of veterinary care must include vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly
diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests
(including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending
veterinarian.
Correction Date: July 22nd, 2024

During inspection, a female chow dog was noted to be sheading much of her undercoat. The shed around the backs of
her ears had become matted and was no longer able to fall out on its own.
Matting of hair can cause irritation to the skin that can lead to infection and/or discomfort for the dog.
Each breeder must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing,
and signed by the attending veterinarian. The written program of veterinary care must ensure preventative care and
treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and
teeth.
Correction Date: July 19th, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
During inspection it was noted that six chow dogs and three six-month old puppies did not have any form of identification.  
All dogs, including puppies, must have distinctive identification so that animals can be identified in the case of an animal 
disease outbreak, and to identify specific animals that may require routine or veterinary care. Class “A” breeders shall 
identify all dogs under his control or on his premises, whether held, purchased, or otherwise acquired.  
All dogs and puppies held at the facility must have a distinctive identification. 
Correction Date: July 22nd, 2024 
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The play yard that is primarily used for young dogs and smaller dogs had a hole that was dug under the south west most 
kennel.  
The hole could lead to dogs becoming stuck in the hole or in the flooring of the kennel above which could lead to injury of 
the dogs.  
Housing facilities for dogs and cats must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be 
kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals 
from entering. 
Correction date: July 19th, 2024 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
There was no written exercise plan available at the time of inspection. 
Exercise for dogs is critical for healthy development and psychological well-being.  
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with 
the opportunity for exercise. In addition, the plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan must include 
written standard procedures to be followed in providing the opportunity for exercise. 
Correction Date: July 22nd, 2024 
3.13(a)(3)

Veterinary care for dogs. 
There were no records of the adult dogs in the kennel receiving parvovirus and distemper vaccines. The facility 
representative reported that the vaccines are normally given when the dogs whelp but it has not been done for the last 
few litters. The is no program for when the males in the kennel are to be vaccinated.  
Failure to vaccinate dogs leaves them vulnerable illness, and disease that could lead to death.  
Each breeder must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, 
and signed by the attending veterinarian. Breeders must keep and maintain the written program and make it available for 
APHIS inspection. The written program of veterinary care must include vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly 
diseases of dogs (including rabies, parvovirus and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests 
(including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending 
veterinarian. 
Correction Date: July 22nd, 2024 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
During inspection, a female chow dog was noted to be sheading much of her undercoat. The shed around the backs of 
her ears had become matted and was no longer able to fall out on its own.  
Matting of hair can cause irritation to the skin that can lead to infection and/or discomfort for the dog.  
 Each breeder must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented in writing, 
and signed by the attending veterinarian. The written program of veterinary care must ensure preventative care and 
treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and 
teeth. 
Correction Date: July 19th, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
